focus_skills: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables

questions.question: If <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>19</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Add 5 to both sides of the equation: <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>24</mn></math>. Divide both sides by 4: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Isolate the variable term first by performing inverse operations (addition/subtraction) before addressing the coefficient (multiplication/division).

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='200' viewBox='0 0 300 200' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><polygon points='50,150 200,150 50,50' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><rect x='50' y='135' width='15' height='15' fill='none' stroke='black' /><text x='110' y='170' font-family='Arial' font-size='16'>12</text><text x='25' y='100' font-family='Arial' font-size='16'>5</text><text x='130' y='90' font-family='Arial' font-size='16'>c</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A right triangle with legs of length 5 and 12. The hypotenuse is labeled c.
questions.question: The right triangle shown has legs with lengths of 5 units and 12 units. What is the value of <math><mi>c</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Using the Pythagorean theorem <math><msup><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>b</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>c</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>: <math><msup><mn>5</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mn>12</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>c</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. This simplifies to <math><mn>25</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>144</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>169</mn></math>. Taking the square root, <math><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Memorize common Pythagorean triples like 3-4-5 and 5-12-13 to solve these problems instantly without calculation.

questions.question: A biologist estimates that a certain bacterial culture contains 250 organisms. If the population increases by 20% over the next hour, how many organisms will be in the culture?
questions.explanation: Calculate the increase: <math><mn>250</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>0.20</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>50</mn></math>. Add this to the original amount: <math><mn>250</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>50</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>300</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To increase a number by P%, you can multiply the original number by (1 + P/100). Here, 250 * 1.2 = 300.

questions.question: Which value of <math><mi>x</mi></math> is a solution to the inequality <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>></mo><mn>11</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Add 4 to both sides: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>></mo><mn>15</mn></math>. Divide by 3: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>></mo><mn>5</mn></math>. Of the options, only 6 is greater than 5.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Treat strict inequalities (like >) carefully; the boundary value itself (5 in this case) is not a solution.

questions.skill: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
questions.question:
The system of equations below has solution (x,y). What is the value of x?
y=4x2x+y=18
questions.explanation: Substitute <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi></math> into the second equation: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>18</mn></math>. This simplifies to <math><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>18</mn></math>, so <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When one equation is solved for a variable (like y = 4x), the substitution method is usually faster than elimination.

questions.question: The function <math><mi>f</mi></math> is defined by <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. What is the value of <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation: Substitute <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></math> into the function: <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. <math><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Be extremely careful when squaring negative numbers. (-2)^2 is positive 4, not -4.

questions.question: In a right triangle, the measures of the two acute angles are <math><mi>R</mi></math> and <math><mi>S</mi></math>. If <math><mi>sin</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>R</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>7</mn><mn>25</mn></mfrac></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>cos</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>S</mi><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation: In a right triangle, the acute angles are complementary, meaning <math><mi>R</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>S</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>90</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. A key identity is <math><mi>sin</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>90</mn><mo>°</mo><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></math>. Therefore, <math><mi>sin</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>R</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>S</mi><mo>)</mo></math>. The value is <math><mfrac><mn>7</mn><mn>25</mn></mfrac></math> or 0.28.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember the complementary angle theorem: Sine of an angle equals the Cosine of its complement.

questions.question: Which expression is equivalent to <math><msup><mi>a</mi><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></msup><mo>·</mo><msup><mi>a</mi><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></msup></math>, where <math><mi>a</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: When multiplying terms with the same base, add the exponents: <math><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>. Find a common denominator (6): <math><mfrac><mn>8</mn><mn>6</mn></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>6</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>11</mn><mn>6</mn></mfrac></math>. The result is <math><msup><mi>a</mi><mfrac><mn>11</mn><mn>6</mn></mfrac></msup></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To add fractions with different denominators, always find the Least Common Multiple (LCM) for the denominator first.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='350' height='200' viewBox='0 0 350 200' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><line x1='30' y1='150' x2='320' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><circle cx='50' cy='130' r='5' fill='black' /><circle cx='50' cy='115' r='5' fill='black' /><circle cx='100' cy='130' r='5' fill='black' /><circle cx='100' cy='115' r='5' fill='black' /><circle cx='100' cy='100' r='5' fill='black' /><circle cx='150' cy='130' r='5' fill='black' /><circle cx='200' cy='130' r='5' fill='black' /><circle cx='250' cy='130' r='5' fill='black' /><circle cx='250' cy='115' r='5' fill='black' /><circle cx='250' cy='100' r='5' fill='black' /><circle cx='250' cy='85' r='5' fill='black' /><text x='45' y='170' font-family='Arial'>1</text><text x='95' y='170' font-family='Arial'>2</text><text x='145' y='170' font-family='Arial'>3</text><text x='195' y='170' font-family='Arial'>4</text><text x='245' y='170' font-family='Arial'>5</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A dot plot showing data values. Value 1 has 2 dots, Value 2 has 3 dots, Value 3 has 1 dot, Value 4 has 1 dot, and Value 5 has 4 dots.
questions.question: The dot plot shows the distribution of a dataset. What is the median of the data?
questions.explanation: Count the total dots: <math><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>11</mn></math> data points. The median is the <math><mn>6</mn></math>th value when ordered. The first 2 are '1', the next 3 are '2' (positions 3, 4, 5). The 6th value falls in the '3' column.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To find the median position in a set of N numbers, calculate (N+1)/2. For 11 items, (11+1)/2 = 6th item.

questions.question: Triangle <math><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is a right triangle with the right angle at <math><mi>B</mi></math>. If <math><mi>tan</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math> and the length of leg <math><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></math> is 16, what is the length of leg <math><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: In right triangle ABC with right angle B, <math><mi>tan</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mtext>opposite</mtext><mtext>adjacent</mtext></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></mrow></mfrac></math>. We are given <math><mi>tan</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math> and <math><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn></math>. So, <math><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow><mn>16</mn></mfrac></math>. Multiply by 16: <math><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>×</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Draw a sketch for every trig problem. Identify 'Opposite' and 'Adjacent' sides relative to the specific angle mentioned.

questions.question: The total cost <math><mi>C</mi></math>, in dollars, to rent a piece of heavy machinery for <math><mi>h</mi></math> hours is given by the equation <math><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>125</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>45</mn><mi>h</mi></math>. What is the best interpretation of the value 45 in this context?

options.A: The flat fee to rent the machinery.
options.B: The total cost to rent the machinery for one day.
options.C: The cost per hour of renting the machinery.
options.D: The number of hours the machinery can be rented for $125.

questions.explanation: The equation is in the form <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math>. The slope, 45, represents the rate of change, which is the cost added for each additional hour of rental.
questions.score_improvement_tip: In linear models, the coefficient of the variable (slope) is always a rate (e.g., dollars per hour), while the constant term (y-intercept) is the starting value or flat fee.

questions.question: For the quadratic equation <math><mn>2</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, where <math><mi>k</mi></math> is a constant, the equation has exactly one real solution. What is the value of <math><mi>k</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: A quadratic equation has exactly one real solution when the discriminant <math><msup><mi>b</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>a</mi><mi>c</mi></math> is equal to zero. Here <math><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>, <math><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>8</mn></math>, and <math><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>k</mi></math>. <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. <math><mn>64</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. <math><mn>8</mn><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>64</mn></math>, so <math><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Discriminant rules: Positive = 2 real solutions; Zero = 1 real solution; Negative = No real solutions.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='150' viewBox='0 0 400 150' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect x='50' y='20' width='300' height='100' fill='none' stroke='black' /><line x1='50' y1='50' x2='350' y2='50' stroke='black' /><line x1='150' y1='20' x2='150' y2='120' stroke='black' /><line x1='250' y1='20' x2='250' y2='120' stroke='black' /><text x='80' y='40' font-family='Arial' font-weight='bold'>Type</text><text x='180' y='40' font-family='Arial' font-weight='bold'>Group A</text><text x='280' y='40' font-family='Arial' font-weight='bold'>Group B</text><text x='80' y='80' font-family='Arial'>Success</text><text x='180' y='80' font-family='Arial'>32</text><text x='280' y='80' font-family='Arial'>18</text><text x='80' y='110' font-family='Arial'>Failure</text><text x='180' y='110' font-family='Arial'>8</text><text x='280' y='110' font-family='Arial'>42</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A contingency table. Group A: 32 Success, 8 Failure. Group B: 18 Success, 42 Failure.
questions.question: The table shows the results of an experiment for two groups. If a result is selected at random from the 'Success' category, what is the probability that it came from Group A?
questions.explanation: This is a conditional probability. We are limited to the 'Success' row. Total successes = <math><mn>32</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>18</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>50</mn></math>. The number of successes from Group A is 32. Probability = <math><mfrac><mn>32</mn><mn>50</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>0.64</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For conditional probability, the denominator is the total of the *condition* (here, all Successes), not the grand total of all data points.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='250' viewBox='0 0 300 250' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='300' height='250' fill='white' /><polygon points='50,220 125,220 50,40' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><rect x='50' y='205' width='15' height='15' fill='none' stroke='black' /><text x='45' y='30' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>A</text><text x='130' y='230' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>C</text><text x='30' y='230' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>B</text><text x='95' y='140' font-family='serif' font-size='14'>39</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A right triangle ABC with the right angle at vertex B. Segment AB is the longer vertical leg, and segment BC is the shorter horizontal leg. Vertex A is at the top, B is at the bottom-left, and C is at the bottom-right. The hypotenuse AC is labeled 39.
questions.question: In right triangle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> with right angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>B</mi></math>, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>tan</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>5</mn><mn>12</mn></mfrac></math>. If the hypotenuse <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>39</mn></math> units long, what is the perimeter of the triangle?
questions.explanation: We are given <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>tan</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>o</mi><mi>p</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>d</mi><mi>j</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>5</mn><mn>12</mn></mfrac></math>. This implies the triangle's sides correspond to the Pythagorean triple <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>5</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>13</mn></math>. The ratio of the hypotenuse in the primitive triple is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>13</mn></math>, but the actual hypotenuse is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>39</mn></math>. We find the scale factor <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>k</mi></math> by dividing the actual length by the triple length: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>39</mn><mn>13</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>.  Multiplying the legs of the primitive triple by <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>3</mn></math>, we get the actual side lengths: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>36</mn></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn></math>. The perimeter is the sum of all sides: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>15</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>36</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>39</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>90</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='250' viewBox='0 0 300 250' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='300' height='250' fill='white' /><polygon points='50,220 125,220 50,40' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><rect x='50' y='205' width='15' height='15' fill='none' stroke='black' /><text x='45' y='30' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>A</text><text x='130' y='230' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>C</text><text x='30' y='230' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>B</text><text x='30' y='140' font-family='serif' font-size='14' fill='red'>36</text><text x='80' y='240' font-family='serif' font-size='14' fill='red'>15</text><text x='95' y='140' font-family='serif' font-size='14'>39</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The same right triangle with the calculated leg lengths labeled in red: leg AB is 36 and leg BC is 15.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Memorize common Pythagorean triples like 3-4-5, 5-12-13, and 8-15-17. If you see a ratio matching these, check the scale factor immediately.

questions.question: What is the sum of the x-coordinates of the solutions to the system of equations defined by <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></math> and <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Set equations equal: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. Rearrange: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Factor: <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Solutions for x are 1 and 5. Sum = <math><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>. Alternatively, use sum of roots formula <math><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mi>b</mi><mi>a</mi></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow><mn>1</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For the sum of roots of a quadratic ax^2 + bx + c = 0, use -b/a directly without solving for each root.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='300' viewBox='0 0 300 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='300' height='300' fill='white' /><line x1='40' y1='260' x2='280' y2='260' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='40' y1='260' x2='40' y2='20' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='35' y='280' font-size='12'>0</text><text x='140' y='280' font-size='12'>10</text><text x='240' y='280' font-size='12'>20</text><text x='20' y='265' font-size='12'>0</text><text x='15' y='160' font-size='12'>10</text><text x='15' y='60' font-size='12'>20</text><circle cx='60' cy='238' r='3' fill='black'/><circle cx='80' cy='220' r='3' fill='black'/><circle cx='100' cy='195' r='3' fill='black'/><circle cx='120' cy='185' r='3' fill='black'/><circle cx='140' cy='160' r='3' fill='black'/><circle cx='160' cy='150' r='3' fill='black'/><circle cx='180' cy='125' r='3' fill='black'/><circle cx='200' cy='110' r='3' fill='black'/><circle cx='220' cy='95' r='3' fill='black'/><circle cx='240' cy='75' r='3' fill='black'/><line x1='40' y1='240' x2='260' y2='42' stroke='red' stroke-dasharray='5,5' stroke-width='2'/></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A scatterplot with an x-axis and y-axis labeled from 0 to 20. The points are clustered in a narrow band rising from the bottom-left to the top-right. A line of best fit (dashed red) passes roughly through (0, 2) and (20, 20), indicating a positive slope of approximately 1.
questions.question: A scatterplot showing the relationship between variables <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi></math> is shown along with a line of best fit. Which equation best models the data?
questions.explanation:
To determine the best model, analyze the shape and direction of the points.
1. **Direction:** The points rise from left to right, indicating a positive slope. This eliminates Option B (negative slope).
2. **Shape:** The pattern is linear (straight line), not curved. This eliminates Option D (exponential).
3. **Slope Magnitude:** The line rises roughly 1 unit of y for every 1 unit of x (e.g., from x=0 to x=20, y goes from ≈2 to ≈20). This corresponds to a slope near 1. Option C has a slope of 2.5, which would be much steeper. Option A (slope=0.9) fits the visual data best.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='300' viewBox='0 0 300 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='300' height='300' fill='white' /><line x1='40' y1='260' x2='280' y2='260' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='40' y1='260' x2='40' y2='20' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='35' y='280' font-size='12'>0</text><text x='140' y='280' font-size='12'>10</text><text x='240' y='280' font-size='12'>20</text><text x='20' y='265' font-size='12'>0</text><text x='15' y='160' font-size='12'>10</text><text x='15' y='60' font-size='12'>20</text><line x1='40' y1='240' x2='260' y2='42' stroke='red' stroke-dasharray='5,5' stroke-width='2'/><text x='100' y='120' font-size='14' fill='red' font-weight='bold'>Slope ≈ 1</text><path d='M 140 150 L 180 150 L 180 114' fill='none' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2'/><text x='150' y='165' font-size='12' fill='blue'>run</text><text x='185' y='140' font-size='12' fill='blue'>rise</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The scatterplot with annotations showing the 'rise' and 'run' of the line of best fit, visually demonstrating a slope closer to 1 (0.9) than to 2.5.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Check the slope direction (positive/negative) first, then estimate the steepness (rise over run) to distinguish between remaining positive linear options.

questions.question: The equation of a circle in the xy-plane is <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>11</mn></math>. What is the radius of the circle?
questions.explanation: Complete the square for x and y. <math><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>11</mn></math>. Add <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mn>6</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math> and <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mn>8</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn></math> to both sides. <math><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>11</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>16</mn></math>. <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>36</mn></math>. <math><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>36</mn></math>, so radius <math><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To complete the square for x^2 + bx, add (b/2)^2 to both sides of the equation.

questions.question: For the linear equation <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math>, a second linear equation is <math><mi>a</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>15</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></math>. If the system of these two equations has no solution, what is the value of <math><mi>a</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: For a system to have no solution, the lines must be parallel, meaning their slopes are equal (or coefficients of x and y are proportional) but the constants are not. Ratio of y-coefficients is <math><mfrac><mn>15</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. The x-coefficients must have the same ratio: <math><mfrac><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. Solving for a gives <math><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: No solution means parallel lines. This requires the ratio of x-coefficients to equal the ratio of y-coefficients.

questions.question: Which of the following expressions is equivalent to <math><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mrow><msqrt><mi>x</mi></msqrt><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac></math>?
questions.explanation: Rationalize the denominator by multiplying numerator and denominator by the conjugate <math><msqrt><mi>x</mi></msqrt><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. Numerator: <math><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><msqrt><mi>x</mi></msqrt><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msqrt><mi>x</mi></msqrt><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn></math>. Denominator: <math><mo>(</mo><msqrt><mi>x</mi></msqrt><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><msqrt><mi>x</mi></msqrt><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>9</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To remove a square root from a binomial denominator, multiply by the conjugate (change the sign in the middle).

questions.question: A right circular cylinder has a volume of 400 cubic units. If the radius of the base is halved and the height is doubled, what is the volume of the new cylinder?
questions.explanation: Original Volume <math><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>400</mn></math>. New radius <math><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.5</mn><mi>r</mi></math>. New height <math><msub><mi>h</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>h</mi></math>. New Volume <math><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0.5</mn><mi>r</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>h</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>0.25</mn><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>h</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0.5</mn><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>h</mi></math>. <math><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.5</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>400</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>200</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When dimensions change by a factor, square the factor for area/radius components in the formula.
